title: Experience
text:
Baseball Research & Development Intern
January - August 2025
During my internship with the Rays, I focused on building tools and models to support player evaluation and decision-making:

I developed an R Shiny application that automatically identified concerning amateur pitchers, streamlining the scouting process and saving the staff 100+ hours of manual tagging.
I trained an XGBoost model to evaluate and predict baserunning reads on more than 150,000 batted balls dating back to 2015, helping quantify a previously hard-to-measure skill.
I created an automated RMarkdown reporting system for park factor corrections, improving the accuracy of draft prospect evaluations across different playing environments.

These projects combined statistical modeling, data engineering, and visualization to deliver tools that directly supported the Rays’ front office and scouting operations.

title: Experience
text:
Rice Football
Student Head of Analytics
August 2022 - Present
I’ve been part of Rice Football since my very first week of college, starting as a video operations intern filming practices and games for the coaching staff. After one semester, I transitioned into recruiting and scouting, where I evaluated prospects through extensive video review and led official/unofficial visits for recruits and their families.
By my sophomore year, I helped build out Rice’s first student-led analytics department, which has since grown from just 2 people to a team of 12. In this role, I’ve led projects that directly supported coaches and recruiting staff, including:

Developing analytics-based scouting reports for weekly opponents.
Creating machine learning models to project transfer portal entries and estimate the likelihood of players transferring to Rice.
Designing a R Shiny web application to automate opponent scouting processes.
Assisting in the evaluation of every Texas Class of 2024 high school prospect.

This experience has given me hands-on exposure to multiple aspects of a Division I football program (video operations, recruiting, scouting, and analytics) while also allowing me to lead and mentor a growing team of student analysts.

title: Experience
text:
Carnegie Mellon University
Undergraduate Researcher - Department of Statistics and Data Science
June - August 2024
I was one of 15 students selected for a fully-funded 8-week research program at Carnegie Mellon’s Department of Statistics & Data Science, where I applied advanced statistical methods to problems in sports analytics.
My capstone project, “Batted Passes in the NFL: A Hierarchical Approach to Explaining Variance of an Unlikely Event” (advised by Dr. Ron Yurko), investigated the drivers behind one of football’s rarest but impactful plays. Using a mixed-effects logistic regression model, I:

Quantified how play context, quarterback tendencies, and defensive pressure contribute to batted passes.
Generated quarterback rankings based on random effect estimates of their ability to avoid batted passes.
Produced a full paper, poster, and presentation, which I presented at the 2024 Carnegie Mellon Sports Analytics Conference.

This experience deepened my skills in hierarchical modeling, statistical inference, and communicating results to both technical and non-technical audiences.

title: Experience
text:
Montgomery Sports Group
Basketball Analytics Intern
June - August 2023
Montgomery Sports Group is a small basketball agency with just two full-time agents, which gave me the opportunity to make a direct impact on player scouting and evaluation. My role combined traditional film breakdown with analytics-based research, producing insights that were used in client recruitment and representation.
Highlights:

Authored 15+ video and written scouting reports that blended film study with statistical analysis, used in player meetings. You can find an example written report here as well as an example video here.
Evaluated prospects with Synergy Sports data to project NBA success and long-term earning potential.
Expanded the agency’s prospect database by adding 50+ players, each with detailed evaluations and backgrounds.
Conducted market research on NBA free agency moves, identifying ideal destinations and opportunities for clients.
Designed an in-depth pitch deck for a prospective NBA client that was presented in agency meetings.

This experience gave me a close look at the business and strategy side of basketball, while allowing me to contribute meaningfully to scouting and player evaluation processes.

title: CMSACamp Capstone Project
text:
Research Question: How can we best explain the variance of batted passes in the NFL on a play-by-play basis?
Utilized a multilevel model taking into account quarterback and defensive team as random effects, with information about the play (ex. formation, pass location) as fixed effects.

title: 2025 Big Data Bowl Submission
text: 2025 Big Data Bowl Submission focused on predicting whether tight ends would block or not pre-snap. Applied Gaussian Mixture Model to categorize pre-snap movement as well as Recurrent Neural Network for a frame-by-frame view of blocking probabilities.

title: 2024 SMT Data Challenge Submission
text: Project focused on optimizing batting order in minor league baseball using farm system data provided by SMT. Multifaceted approach to game simulation taking into account baserunner speed, pitcher fatigue, directional tendencies, and more.

title: Intro to Sport Analytics Final Project
text: Utilized logistic regression to create an expected points model for the NBA 2023-24 regular season. Explored potential applications in team evaluation, predictive power, and player evaluation of scoring ability (both on-ball and off-ball), including building a Regularized Adjusted Plus-Minus metric.

title: 2026 Big Data Bowl Submission
text: 2026 NFL Big Data Bowl submission focused on quantifying coverage defender positioning while the ball is in the air. Utilized Random Forest Conditional Density Estimation for constructing distribution of “ghost” defenders, XGBoost for estimating catch probability, and mixed-effects modeling for computing player talent estimates.

title: Lucca Ferraz
text:
Welcome to my website! I am a Senior at Rice University majoring in Statistics and Sport Analytics, with minors in Data Science and Financial Computation and Modeling.
I am a mathematically-oriented thinker interested in using data to solve complex problems in the real-world. My career interests lie in sport analytics, quantitative finance, and data science. Throughout my coursework, internships, and passion projects, I have developed skills in R, Python, and SQL.
In my free time, you can find me playing basketball, chess, and the tuba. Please have a look around my website, and feel free to contact me if you have any questions or want to connect!
